reviewText:
Overall, I quite enjoyed The Ritual on Weylyn Island. The game mixes itself up and comes off as a low-budget attempt to make an interesting sort of cinematic horror experience, one that has actual diversity in gameplay, setting, tasks, and knows how to pace itself and keep things interesting. A few scenes can even be startling or unnerving. This all comes with an edge of low-budget elements, including some wonky animations and a level of jank to things. However, the ambition and successful execution of many of its concepts makes it an enjoyable 1.5-2 hour experience to go through (appropriately about the length of a horror movie).

The basic idea is you play as a girl name Moira, who has come a bit after the rest of her family to Weylyn Island, an island her rich grandfather had purchased and passes down to his family upon his death (along with his riches and possessions). They go to stake claim to the place, and to help strengthen some family ties that have grown a bit distant recently. However, a strange cult has invaded the island, and now seem to want the family dead. And thus, it becomes a tiresome night of having to evade cultists, ritualistic shrines, and discover what exactly is going on here.

And it mostly succeeds. In big part due to it being able to keep the player guessing, a variety of settings, tasks, and solid core mechanics, matched with feeling involved in every moment of the action going on. Whether it be exploring the quiet coast of the island, evading a silent stalker in a basement, or investigating a strange altar with a music box, the game is full of interesting scenes matched with good atmosphere and a level of intrigue accomplished by good vision and direction.

There are a few flaws here; The story is predictable as all hell, the finale while not quite disappointing feels like it could be more. While the game is worth playing through to the end, I feel the first half of the game was better fleshed-out and realized, with the second half feeling a bit more linear and sometimes coming off as more scripted. A few areas do feel they could be tighter designed, such as a scene where you're in a house looking for a key and something is banging on the door, but no matter how long you take the door will just keep banging, smudging much of the tension there. But even despite all of this, there is a very solid little horror experience in this title. The length might put some off, but it doesn't feel they padded the game to make it longer and do keep the variety and overall quality at a higher-than-average aspect to indie horror developers. In some ways, it feels like maybe their ambition was a bit over their heads, but for this to be a mostly well-realized vision is quite an accomplishment.

But I point out these flaws as I feel the game itself is quite solid. Not the best horror game I've played, but a pretty well-done foray with a few interesting twists and turns up its sleeves to keep the 1.5-2 hour experience interesting. It's also notable the game avoids many indie horror pitfalls; the game has a good level of darkness (you never can't see what's going on and it looks like its night rather than pitch dark), your flashlight has no batteries and is actually quite efficient, there is no limited sprinting, it doesn't rely on jump scares, there isn't much in the way of key collecting, it doesn't come off as a clone of any popular indie horror game and there's no clone segments designed after Slender or FNAF or something (this comparison isn't the best, but the thing I find myself comparing it the closest to would be Call of Cthulhu: Dark Corners of the Earth, which it reminded me a bit of), the writing is good and isn't full of typos and grammar mistakes, the voice acting is pretty decent, among other things. But it doesn't accomplish it goals because of it not failing, it is a competent and often engaging journey on its own.

If you like cult horror (as in, literally about cults and figuratively), indie horror games with a lot of heart, don't mind a low-budgeted game with deep ambitions, and overall don't mind the price tag to the hours it might provide of entertainment, I say definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

'DEVIL WORSHIPPERS INVADE FAMILY ISLAND!', yeah, this could absolutely be one of those weird early eighties action flicks or, if it's unlucky, a slightly more recent Steven Seagal movie.
With only the first three chapters sketched out and playable thus far, The Ritual on Weylyn Island is giving a very solid account of itself. Cult plots are usually too saturated in cheese to grind any fear from but the game establishes their brutality early as you arrive at a family residence to find blood, broken glass, defaced pictures and arcane graffiti. Your first encounter with the invaders is similarly unsettling; fleeing through a dense wood, you veer off onto narrow branching paths, forced to suddenly retreat as you almost run into the outstretched hands of robed figures.
There's no combat to speak of, aside from a QTE, and the best thing TROWI could do is keep it that way. This isn't a difficult game; there are no puzzles beyond figuring out which box to barricade a door with but it is the engaging equivalent of a walk through a haunted house.
Apart from the tightening up of interaction UI and some unfinished sound cues, my advice to the developers is mainly plot orientated. I'd ditch the opening cutscene. It looks like crap and acheives nothing. Tighten up the dialogue. Keep the cult in the shadows. I could really have done without the demonically possessed family members hissing and swearing; I think the atmosphere is better served by the hooded cultists but if they have to stay, keep their mouths shut.
Definitely heading in the right direction. Check it out:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ynifepPD7iI

reviewText:
The Ritual on Weylyn Island, developed by zemaGamez, had the potential to bring back all of your favorite horror tropes, and that’s probably what the devs had in mind. However, due to poor presentation, an unfulfilled story, and hollow characters, Weylyn Island stumbles and falls before it can provide the homage it strives to represent.

You play as Moria Weylyn; a typical collage girl without any defining traits or skills. Her grandfather had recently died, and in his will, Moria and a handful of family members are given the isolated island he once called home; Blessed Island. (Odd, seeing as how the game’s title is Weylyn Island, yet it’s clearly called Blessed Island throughout the story. But I digress.)

These family members include: Uncle Brian, his two kids, Fin and Megan, and Moria’s older sister, Row. Plans were made to meet up on the island, but a freak storm delays Moria’s trip. Arriving one day after her family, she sets foot on the cold, wet dwarf and heads out.

In all honesty, Weylyn Island starts out really strong. The Island’s dark and laced in shadows, and your first few minutes are spent soaking up the atmosphere. I mean, you’ve got a bunch of unsuspecting teens (and one adult) on a secluded, creepy island. The possibilities are endless! Your first real objective is to head up to the old cabin, where your family is supposedly waiting for you. As I trudged down the trailside, bombarded by endless rain, I could only imagine what sort of horrors awaited me.

Sadly, that’s about the extent of this game’s suspense and intrigue.

Before going any further, we might as well talk graphics. And they’re… alright. I mean, Weylyn Island isn’t ugly by any stretch of the word, but its design is easily forgettable. The grey, overbearing tone works wonders at first, building upon the mood of the setting. But endless rain, pine trees and monochrome color pallets only go so far. Again, this game’s level design isn’t bad, but only decent. As for character models… well, that’s another story.

Their textures are basic at best and look far from appealing, but they manage. But it’s their animations that really bite the dust; everyone walks like they’ve got a wooden plank shoved up their ♥♥♥.

But let’s be real: you don’t need high budget visuals or picturesque designs to make something scary. If done correctly, a game with ugly graphics can be forgiven if its got a solid story and solid gameplay. I mean, a build up with this much potential is sure to lead to something good, right?

Right…?

As for gameplay, there’s little to speak of. Long bouts of walking and quick-time-events are in high abundance, topped off with not-so-scary chase scenes, and most of these are void of sound effects or tracks. The results are less intense and more uncomfortable (and no, not in a good way).

But despite all of this, it’s Weylyn Island’s story that ruined the entire game for me. Hell, I could forgive all these flaws had the plot been (at least) good.

But nope, it isn’t. I won’t spoil anything, but it’s got everything required to tell a lame horror story. There’s practically zero explanation until the third act, which left me more confused and less terrified most of the time. Some of these characters don’t even ♥♥♥♥ing talk! We’re watching them suffer and die but… why should I care?  One of them had little more than two lines of dialogue, and another was only capable of squealing and whining. Jesus, one of them didn’t get a chance to talk before kicking the bucket!  All of their voice actors were terrible, especially your character’s. I’ve seen sloths with more dedication than this ♥♥♥♥♥.

The game also thinks that long sessions of poetry recited by old men is scary. It isn't. This is Weylyn Island’s #1 method of storytelling, and it’s done awfully.

This game just makes me mad. God, it’s even forced me to type up my longest review yet. But when a story with so much possibility fails to strike almost every note, it just leaves me baffled. “What went wrong,” I think to myself. “What. Went . Wrong?”

reviewText:
Indie Survival Horror: Much like the movie industry it seems that its the indie developers who make the majority of horror titles. That means that there’s a lot of great art house style games available to buy but there is a lot of utter crap that gets published. Separating the strong from the weak isn’t always the easiest in this genre because the worst often gets heavy promotion while the good, solid, titles often get ignored. The Ritual on Weylyn Island is a game that is likely to be ignored despite it being a very solid and reasonable entry into a crowded marketplace.

Suitable graphics but a couple of minor letdowns: This is a game that does not rely on its graphics to tell the story. However, what is there helps establish the atmosphere very well. It’s color palette was extremely well chosen. It is gloomy, foreboding, etc. It is everything that you would expect a horror story located on an isolated island to be. There are a few letdowns graphically as occasionally the particular thing you need to go to isn’t very clear. For example, there is a part where you need to find a trap door in a room in order to progress through to the next stage of the story. I searched that room several times and couldn’t find anything and thus I googled the solution and a found a video that showed me where it was.  I’d also have appreciated a little bit more work into the character design. They’re not anyone that you’re going to remember after you’ve played the game art wise.

Inconsistent voice work: I must admit that I watched the Jim Sterling video on this game prior to playing. He pointed out that the voice over work occasionally sounds like it was made in two different rooms. I agree with him. The level is wildly inconsistent throughout but as he said that’s indie games for you. It’s a minor quibble but it is noticeable. I must admit that I loved the voice recording tapes that you find throughout the game. They add a tremendous amount of backstory to the game and are generally always found at just the right point of the game to make the most impact.

Enjoyable but cliche-ish story: If you’ve read your fair share of horror stories you’re bound to have come across a story similar to The Ritual on Weylyn Island. That’s not necessarily a bad thing but don’t expect the title to add anything new story wise to the genre. It’s very cliche-ish.

But I really enjoyed it: A few of the above points may sound as though I really didn’t appreciate the game yet I found that I did enjoy it. I’ve played a few horror games since I played the horror game of the year of 2015 in the PlayStation 4’s Until Dawn. Although there’s a gulf between the quality of that title and The Ritual on Weylyn Island I just have to suggest that this is a title that I will be returning to at some point with friends.

The Ritual on Weylyn Island is a very solid indie horror game. I believe that it belongs as a solid entry in a Halloween celebration gameathon. It holds its own against other horror games on Steam and is well and truly worthy of the two hours that it will take you to play through it. Consider it a B-grade movie. It’s far from trash but doesn’t have the production value of the very best titles.

For more reviews similar to this one and our daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just finished playing the first hour of The Ritual on Weylyn Island and I'm really enjoying the story. Set on an island that the main character and her family have just inherited from the recently deceased grandfather. You are the last to arrive by ferry and find the family has gone up to the lighthouse.

https://youtu.be/ywiPFpMyxfg

The gameplay is a simple interactive first person game. You control the main character and are searching for your family and what the deal is on the island. The story so far has me hooked. The game opens with a cinematic of a man running through the woods, tripping into the center of a ritual circle made of stone. Several hooded figures start to chant loudly. A large man wearing some kind of mask stabs the man in the chest with a sword. Badass opening right?

You then arrive at a cabin in the woods and are told by the captain of the ferry how he's heard stories" about the island that he doesn't wish to repeat. Well
date: screw you buddy. The character you are playing indicated they haven't been there since they were 8. So clearly I don't know these stories and furthermore
recommended:
if they are so messed up why the hell wouldn't you tell the young lady you're dropping off at night. On an island. Alone.

From here you read a note indicating the family is at the lighthouse and you should make your way there. Inside you find a flashlight and a tape recorded message from your creepy grandfather being cryptic about the island.

The story is interesting to me and I'd love to know what is happening on the island. However

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would like to point out that this review reflects the early access version of the game and in no way represents the final product.

The game concept is good. The voice acting is surprisingly decent for an indie developer and the story has a lot of potential. The controls are a little clunky and the lack of an options menu for anything is a tad dissapointing, especially when it comes to gamma settings (I never really found a need for the flashlight in my game play).

The game is supposedly stealth based, but the linear layout, invisible walls and enemies that tend to move faster than you make the stealth next to useless. This is a shame, I would love to have stealth work properly in this and have tried to in some area, but the enemies seem to know where you are at any given time as long as your in range. The best option is to just run past them, even if you get hit, it doesn't seem to do much which takes away from the hectic feel that a horror game should have.

On a plus side, the graphics aren't bad, infact they remind me very much of Vampie: The Masquerade, and the cut scenes are very smooth.

The story is probably the games strongest point in my personal opinion. It's very reminiscent of a B movie, much in the same way as Evil Dead (the original), the Wickerman, and so on. All of which I really enjoy.

Would I recommend this game currently? Thats a toss up. The developers seem active and want feedback, the game itself isn't much, and it does have a lot of potential for a very nice finished game. There are lots of bugs still in the game, nothing overly concerning and most of them seem silly if anything. In the end the choice is yours to make. As for me, I'm glad for the purchase and look forward to seeing it polished into the gem it could be.

reviewText: The Ritual on Weylyn Island is an interesting concept off the bat. Cultists on the island where your family is gathering to mourn the passing of an estranged grandfather? An interesting idea. As good an idea as it is, the game really falls short of being able to call this a game. Gameplay aspects were straight forward, though the picking up triggers could be a little touchy. The actual story was pretty lacking in really making this feel like a game. It sort of was more akin to a slight quicktime-ish event walking simulator. It had a great concept, but it just didn't really get pulled off in a satisfying way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a review of The Ritual On Weylin Island. To simplify I have split my review into four sections; Gameplay, Graphics, Audio, and General.

Gameplay:
TROWI is a dark horror driven game, I personally enjoy the themes of Witchcraft and Satanic Rituals.  There is no combat in this game and I believe that to be a good approach stylistically.  The inability to fight the enemy adds to the overall fear and adrenaline one feels while playing, knowing your only option is to run leaves you with a slight feeling of anxiety.    Adding to this anxiety is the fact that appropriately you are not given obvious direction, giving a feeling of being lost and frightened.
Furthering to the fear aspect is the design of the witches, I find their distorted faces to be particularly disturbing.  They are quite unique and a positive artistic approach in my opinion.
I experienced some minor problems while playing.  First is that the flashlight indicates that it can be turned on with both the F-Key and with a right mouse click, however I found it did not turn on with a right click.  I also found it somewhat odd that between each chapter the flashlight would turn off and I would have to turn it back on.
I discovered a minor error with crouching.  If one crouches while stationary they cannot move while crouched, I was only able to move while crouching if I was already in motion.
The last problems I experienced were both at the pull-bridge.  The first is simply that when you reach the end of the pull bridge the transition from the bridge to the ground seemed somewhat awkward and unconnected, but perhaps that is to critical.  However after crossing the Pull bridge I discovered that your cousin Meghan became stuck and ran in place.  This was particularily bothersome as she is directly in your path and the only way past her is by jumping over her.  She did become unstuck, but I believe this error should be looked into.
the problems I experienced were all minor and did not take away from the overall feel or fun of the game, so I will give the Gameplay 7/10.

Graphics:
Overall the Graphics were smooth and an effective expression of the dark atmosphere of the Game.  I found character movement to be quite fluid for the main character, and the motion of enemies and npc's to be generally natural as well.  I particularly like the fact that you can see your own characters legs, this is an extremely rare effect in first person games and it worked well.  Leg movement was natural and well done and that left me impressed.
To contrast the positive effect of your legs I would like to point out that to me the way Moira raises her hand when passing through obstacles seems unnatural and somewhat sluggish.
I enjoyed the water visuals, I found myself admiring the graphics while crossing a bridge early in the game, I also feel that the forest, trees and paths are very well done and added to the atmosphere.
Some things I would like to point out however mostly centered around your Grandpa's house.  I found that the glass on the floor of the kitchen flickered on and off as you moved, a small bug.
The mirror effects in the first bathroom I feel needed work, as it looks more like an abstract painting than broken glass.  I would have loved to see any kind of reflection graphic, even through a broken mirror.
The next thing I would like to point out is the oddness of fluids other than bodies of water, Moira's Grandpa appears to have a jar of solidified camoflauge colored alcohol in his dining room.  Also later in the story when you reach the building that connects to the light house, there is a skeleton in a bathtub filled with what appears to be  jam, lol.
Upon first viewing the light house you are given a short clip of the rotating light, overall the effect was well done, however the leaves on the trees seem to pop into existence unnaturally when bathed in light.
One last silly thing I would like to adress is the appearance of crows over the pull-bridge. They seem to warp in and out of existence. Either this is from the witches black magic"  or it is simply an incomplete graphic. However I will also add it is barely noticeable.
Generally the graphics were quite well done for a game of this size
date:
and any small quirks did not effect the atmosphere much or take away from the artistic direction. I would give the graphics a 7/10.

Audio:
While first approaching the island one of the first sound effects you hear is the rain and waves. I was impressed with both of these effects and their authentic sound. The transition of the effect between being outside and inside is smooth and well done
recommended: and the effect of rain drumming on the roof is a nice touch.\nOther sound effects that I appreciated were those of the frogs when passing by a small body of water
hoursPlayed: they were natural sounding and added to the effect of the forests ambience
voteText: I only wish there were more effects like this to make the forest come alive so-to-speak.  At one point there were crows crying from the trees
helpfulPercent: this effect started off well enough
votesHelpful: but quickly became cluttered and unnatural
votesTotal: followed by a sudden stop in the audio instead of a more natural fading effect. I would even suggest having the effect of flapping wings indicating they were startled and all flew away.\nThe whispering of the witches while navigating the early parts of the forest were creepy and well done
votesFunny: however when they repeat the same phrase 3-4 times in a row it immediately became humourus instead of frightening.\nThe voice acting of the game is a bit of a let down. Moira's voice from start to finish has a reverberation that makes the voice feel very disconnected from the character
commentsCount: almost as if it were playing from her cassette player.  I believe this originates from the recording process and is the result of either distance from the microphone
column16: or recording levels were not set appropriately in advance.  Regardless of where this effect originates
column17: every time Moira spoke I was imagining the voice actor speaking into a microphone instead of the character actually speaking herself.\nIn general I must say the voice acting felt quite unnatural
column18: as if it were read directly off of a paper.\nThere was an obvious crackling during the scene where the man was lit on fire
column19: and all the audio surrounding that scene felt quite weak.  I personally feel that when dealing with emotions such a fear
column20: the uninspired audio and lack of heart did in fact take away from the overal feel of the game.\nOnly adding to the mediocre voice acting was the uninspired music
column21:
where only simple bass notes were used during jump scares.
In light of the audio's strengths and weaknesses I will give it a 5/10

Genral:
Some things that caught my attention
column22: I will not rate this section as not all of them need a fix

column27: how about making a garden?"\nThe other oddity I noticed were barrels  scattered all around the forest
column28: what's in these barrels is a mystery. It is possible they are filled with gas

column32:
dumping barrels around the forest as he pleases.

Overall I enjoyed this game

reviewText:
Summary: A fun, first-person horror game that does not overstay its welcome.

This game is about 1.5 hours long and, much like a typical horror movie, that seems about right.  It is part exploration and part walking simulator. You get to explore areas but much of it is on a linear path. I enjoyed this and it kept the story moving.

I saw a YouTube Let's Play of the first level when it was still in development  (thanks Jim Sterling!) and patiently waited until the game was complete before buying.  I am a fan of creepy horror movies  (not just slashers) that build an atmosphere with sound and visuals and tell a tale. The atmosphere built nicely in this game and the forest sections had the hair on the back of my neck standing up a couple of times. This game cost me about $5 and I feel it was well worth the price of admission. I have certainly paid more for less with other games and other movies. If there was a follow up  product I would get it and that means I would have to recommend it.

reviewText: The game had potential, but the backtracking and detours kills the experience... like many generic horror games these days. Making the game not particularly scary nor fun, just tedious.\n\nAt least they tried though unlike most indie horrors these days. The acting isn't too bad and the overall design is pretty good. Unless you're completely new to these types of games, give it a miss.

reviewText:
An absolute buggy, unplayable piece of crap. The game refuses to even find its own executable file unless the customer manually fixes this problem by running the game as an administrator. Even then, the main character cannot be controlled and the camera endlessly spins around, mixed with a low FOV causes headaches and nausea. The graphics options barely exist, no sensitivity control or true controller support. Whilst the game supports unlocked resolution and framerate the game does not take advantage of these, and in fact, help its own demise. I do not think the developers anticipate people playing above a refresh rate of 60 since the game logic and animations appear to be tied to the framerate.

The game itself, the few minutes I spent with this nightmare: unskippable cutscenes, terrible terrible voice acting, low graphic fedelity with no artistic vision to back it up, generally feels unpolished and uncared for.

I do not recommend this absolute buggy, horrible, terrible piece of crap as it stands right now because it's unplayable and not fit for consuming.

reviewText: I know that Steam players are way too forgiving of horror games, but why the positive reviews? It's just bad. Some of the most terrible audio I've experienced, bad story, wooden animation, broken event triggers, kinda ugly, and not at all fun. The controller support they say they added doesn't actually work properly. If you use one, your character just shifts around when you're not hitting any buttons. Blech. Refunded.
